comments.author: Dan Heidel

comments.text:
+Ryan Masad
Well, I've taken many biochem courses and did about 5 years of labwork in 
bacterial metabolism.  That may be giving me a slanted perspective as in 
that world, glucose is the king of energy transfer.  (And by association, 
glucose is the primary energy source for essentially all life)

This is actually quite interesting as all of the literature I've read 
depicts glucose as the primary energy currency, even in human metabolism.  
I'll take pedia refs, as that's a good starting point. 

I can definitely see a carnivorous creature like cats relying mostly on 
amino acid and fatty acid breakdown for metabolism.  However, I would still 
be surprised if glucose weren't still the largest share of energy transfer 
in humans.  Just because it's a relatively small total energy pool doesn't 
mean that it's not where most of the energy is flowing through because of 
much more rapid cycling.  ATP stores in the human body will only last 1-2 
seconds and are, of course, responsible for essentially 100% of the energy 
used in our bodies.  (fun fact, your body only has a couple grams of ATP in 
it but at a resting state will use at least your body mass of it a day.  In 
athletes, that can be 10 times higher.)
comments.author: Dan Heidel

comments.text: +Dan Heidel +Ryan Masad girls girls girls your both pretty
comments.author: TheABCTree

comments.text:
+Dan Heidel oh I'm sorry, I forgot the references, would Wikipedia be good 
enough?
comments.author: Ryan Masad

comments.text:
Well I don't know a huge amount about plant metabolism, both Hank and 
myself were talking about human biochemistry, so you're final paragraph is 
largely irrelevant, though nice to read.

Although you are almost right about glucose being useful for greater power 
generation, as I said, it's only useful for strenuous exercise. Once 
glycogen stores are depleted athletes "hit the wall" but elite athletes can 
still carry on, usually due to extremely efficient use of the energy 
released from TACs.

Anyway we spend most of our time not running away from lions, and our most 
well used musculature, cardiac muscle, is completely dependant on FA beta 
oxidation, so I think it's fair to say that under normal conditions glucose 
is not the main energy source.

Losing weight is actually extraordinarly easy once the mental desire to 
over indulge is removed, think about gastric band patients whose appetites 
are suppressed.

I mentioned the weight and storage of TACs vs glycogen because is seems 
clear to me that if glucose was used first, we'd run out extremely quickly 
and have to resort to ketones rather too soon, no? As you said, that 
probably wouldn't be healthy.

Did you do a biochemistry degree/course at some point? I'm aware that 
schools tend to overemphasise glucose so they can teach you about diabetes, 
even though that's really also more to do with fat
comments.author: Ryan Masad

comments.text:
+Ryan Masad
Actually those references would be quite interesting.  All of the exercise 
literature I have read firmly states that glycogen is the primary 
limitation on human muscle performance.  If newer information has changed 
that, I would be quite interested to read it. 

Fatty acid and amino acid metabolism can provide a very low baseline power 
level specifically in very slow twitch muscle fibers.  Even trained 
athletes can't muster more than 100-200 watts of body power output on those 
energy reserves which limits you to no more than a fast walk or very 
relaxed jog.  Any exertion beyond that requires muscle glucose metabolism.  
Like I said, I would be genuinely curious to see references to the contrary 
but everything I have read is that glucose is the dominant power source for 
muscles during any non-baseline activity.

I suppose that the body may fall back to non-glucose energy sources for 
baseline exertion levels comparable to sitting in a chain, commenting on 
Youtube.  But that's really not what our musculature was built to be used 
for.

Yes, I am quite aware of the relative energy densities of glycogen vs fat.  
However, just because the body maintains its long-term energy reserves in 
fat, doesn't mean that the latter is our primary energy source.  There is a 
reason that losing weight is so difficult - our bodies have to be in 
overall energy deficit, using up all the glycogen and even breaking down 
muscle tissue before we hit the fat stores to a significant extent.  Keto 
breath isn't exactly a sign of a healthy diet, after all.  But yes, you are 
correct that fatty acid breakdown comes in downstream of glycolysis. It's 
been about a decade since I've had to have those pathways memorized and 
some of them are getting a bit mixed up in my memory. 

But that is all a side note to the basic fact that glucose is by far and 
away the most universal energy source for all life on the planet.  You do 
see a decent number of organisms that can use pyruvate and citrate as  
entry points for their energy source, glucose is king.  The energy 
metabolic pathways we have are most likely all just derived from glycolytic 
metabolism, with various entry points along the way such as acetyl-coA and 
citrate which allows other metabolic sources to tie in to it.  Plants feed 
99.9%+ of the global ecosystem energy flux through glucose.  Everything 
else is just accessories to that energy pathway.
comments.author: Dan Heidel

comments.text:
+Dan Heidel Nope, you've learnt your biochemistry incorrectly mate :), are 
you in school?

It is only possible for humans to store about 300g of glycogen (the polymer 
of glucose) in liver and muscle, because glycogen is an extremely 
inefficient storage of energy. If glycogen was our main energy source we 
would weigh hundreds of kilos more than we do. In fact, once glycogen 
stores are full, excess consumed glucose is stored as TAGs in adipose 
tissue. It's why you get fat if you drink coke all the time. Adipose fat is 
a far more efficient storage medium as it is much denser.
Small quantities of glycogen are indeed stored in muscle to fuel short 
bursts of very strenuous exercise, and glycogenolysis is triggered (in this 
case) by adrenaline. However, under normal conditions, it is fatty acid 
beta-oxidation that provides atp for cellular metabolism. If you don't 
trust me I can provide references, although I'd have thought that it's 
quite obvious that if we used glucose for movement, we'd have to constantly 
eat glucose or go hypoglycaemic! (we can in fact maintain blood glucose for 
10 days a without food, after which the brain switches to ketones.

In the cns and pns (neurons as you put it), glucose is the main energy 
source, for some quite interesting reasons that I'll mention if you are 
interested. However, 25% of brain metabolism is still reliant on one 
particular fatty acid, oxalone. Besides, the nervous system only accounts 
for 20% of oxygen consumption (and therefore metabolic load), so you can't 
call glucose the main fuel source based on that.

You're point about proteins and fats being converted to glycolytic 
intermediares is rather inaccurate. Some amino acids (derived from protein 
in diet or skeletal muscle) like alanine, and the glycerol part of TACs 
are/is converted to pyruvate, which is not glucose despite being in the 
glycolytic pathway, so I'm not sure why you've lumped them all into 
glucose. They simply share some intermediates.

However, most amino acids like glutamine are converted directly into 
a-ketoglutarate, a part of the Krebs cycle. All fatty acids are converted 
into citrate, and it is generally impossible to convert FAs into glucose.

So, in conclusion, although the brain uses glucose as it's main (but not 
only) energy source, the rest of the body uses fat and, to a lesser extent 
peptides, as it's primary fuel. So hank is wrong :P
comments.author: Ryan Masad

comments.text:
+Ryan Masad
No, I'm not talking about blood glucose levels but rather the total 
glucose/glycogen pool of the body.  (which the blood levels are a tiny 
fraction of)  Both muscles and neurons rely almost exclusively on glucose 
as their sole energy input.  Proteins and fat are only used for energy if 
glucose is largely depleted and they have to be converted to glucose (or 
other glycolytic pathway intermediaries) to be burned)

So yes, Hank is correct.  Glucose is the body's main energy source.
comments.author: Dan Heidel

comments.text:
Glycogen (from animals) and starch (from plants) are polysaccharides and 
thus made from alot glucose binded together. So in essence it's all 
glucose. Triglycerides and peptides are mainly used as building materials, 
so it's not used alot for fuel.

comments.text:
+fromMouq
*is unnecessarily down-putting*
I think "flaw" is a very neutral world, flaw in manifacturing doesn't say 
that badly.

*when a term like 'difference' is just as adequate and actually much more 
empirical*
Here I disagree because it'll lump it with things that have no effect on 
anything such as eye colours which it it a different category all together 
from here.

*where apparent 'flaws' (but really 'differences') are often points of 
genesis for what eventual become amazing 'innovations,' if that word can be 
used in a biological sense. *
No, this is where the choice of word makes sense, I use flaw here to mean 
things that are almost exclusively negative and hence has a negative 
selection pressure put upon it in a purely evolutionary sense IF it was 
left to without human social structure.

Differences that makes little to no difference on the individual or come 
with a mix of pros and cons I wouldn't call flaws for that very reason.

I don't say whatever causes the phenomenas in questions are not tied to 
 genes which may under certain genetial circumstances prove advantegous for 
the individual, merely that in that particular instance the manifestation 
is almost exclusively to the detriment of the reproductive success.

But again, for all the political correctness drones out there. I am not 
saying this in any way justifies acts upon anyone because we all carry 
these and everyone still ahve the same fundamental rights from begining of 
life to end.

+EmperorZelos, +950Edward: I don't believe +AlthenaLuna was making any 
attempt to say that it wasn't worth pondering or discussing, I think the 
user's point might have been that 'flaw,' regardless of whether it is the 
correct term or not (which is highly context-dependent) is unnecessarily 
down-putting when a term like 'difference' is just as adequate and actually 
much more empirical, especially if this is a thread where people are going 
to resort to arguments about evolution, where apparent 'flaws' (but really 
'differences') are often points of genesis for what eventual become amazing 
'innovations,' if that word can be used in a biological sense. One can 
argue that asexuality/homosexuality is an exception to this and I'd argue 
that you don't have the omnipotence to know that, especially as it relates 
to +ThePhoenixpaw's comment above. And this is only about the relation of 
the word "flaw" to evolution and genetics -- which you'll notice I think is 
something very distinct from human experience, as I've been arguing with +
rpm2004.

+Nekoko Chan funny enough, one of the original meanings of "flaw," 
according to the OED, is "A flake (of snow); a flake or spark (of fire). 
Obs."

comments.text:
+WrathOfMega The entire point of life is to continue itself, Living beings, 
whether they be animals, plants, fungi or viruses exist solely to replicate 
themselves. They are biological machines built by instructions (DNA) in 
order to create more machines, thus ensuring the survival of the 
instructions. Any error in those instructions that makes it more difficult 
to pass them on to a future generation is a flaw. That doesn't mean they 
are bad people or that they can't significantly contribute to society but 
asexuality, homosexuality, impotence, infertility and birth defects all 
reduce the likelihood of procreation and therefore are counterproductive to 
a species' survival and existence. It doesn't make them bad people in any 
other aspect of their lives, just bad at the main reason for their life 
which is to ensure the continuation of their genes.

comments.author: TheCrazyman5291

comments.text:
well looking at maslow's hierarchy of needs, hung falls under physiological 
needs which is at the bottom, or first in the heirarchy. According to 
maslow you must satisfy one level before moving on. Thus physiological 
needs must be satisfied before anything else, then you move on to safety 
needs, and then to the need to belong. Its not saying that the need to 
belong is more important than hunger, just that physiological needs such as 
hunger must be satisfied before the need to belong. Of course this is not 
always the case, at times you can have motivations that will mess with this 
hierarchy. An example would be say ignoring your need for sleep or food and 
pulling an all nighter to study for a huge test. Im sure there are better 
examples than this, but this is what i could come up with. I hope this 
helps, and sorry in advance if it doesn't. Im not the best at explaining 
things,maybe someone can provide a better answer.

comments.text:
You need an education, which will enable you to have the skills to be good 
at the job you want. You may not need school to get a good education, but 
then if you aren't going to school you need a find another way to obtain 
the knowledge needed to be a profession of that something that you want to 
do, whether it be learning to fish or to become a scientist.

  For most people, school may be the easiest way to get what they want, and 
they will have to put in the effort to get the right rewards out of it. 
People who say that school is useless and doesn't help you in the right 
way, may be right, but then again they may not have tried hard enough, and 
therefore may go on to not work hard in whatever else they do later on in 
life. 

  On the other hand, some people may quit school and find that getting a 
job and real life work experience is what they needed all along. They still 
needed to gain the experience and the lessons learnt from those experiences 
but they didn't need school. 

 You just need to know what you want, and then try to better your self to 
become the right type of person for that kind of job. You can see the 
opportunities that your school can give you and then take them, or you must 
find another way of reaching your goal. Either way, you need that right 
education.

captions.text: You've probably heard this story.

Aron Ralston was out climbing in Utah's Bluejohn
Canyon when a giant rock shifted under his

feet, and he fell, pinning his right arm to
the canyon wall. He was stuck, and worse,
he hadn't told anyone where we was going.

For the next five days, Ralston tried to move
and chip away at the rock. He ate his remaining

food, drank the last of his water. Eventually
he drank his own urine, and started videotaping
his goodbyes.

But then something happened. Ralston had a
dream. He saw himself as a father, picking

up his son, and with that vision, an overpowering
will to survive kicked in. He broke his arm

bones, sawed through his flesh with a dull
pocket knife, and freed himself.

Ralston harnessed some of our most powerful
psychological forces -- hunger, thirst, desire

to be part of a family, need to return to
the human community -- they ignited his tenacity,
which allowed him to do an incredible thing.
He harnessed the power of motivation.
Obviously, in a big, big way.
[INTRO]

In its most basic sense, motivation is the
need or desire to do something. Whether that

need is biological, social, or emotional,
and whether that something is making dinner,

going to college, or cutting off your arm,
motivation is what gets you moving.

But the big question is, why? Why do we do
anything? I mean, why ever bother changing
out of my sweatpants?

Psychologists often view motivation in one
of four ways. On their own, none of these

theories is perfect, but taken together, they
help us understand what drives us. Let's start
with the first theory: an evolutionary perspective.

For a while in the early 20th century, it
was popular to think of all behaviors as instincts,

or innate drives to act a certain way. But
this so-called Instinct Theory was misguided,

in part because the presence of a tendency
doesn't always mean it's supposed to be there.

Like, we can imagine why a bunch of people
might start rioting at a heated soccer match,

but to say that they're supposed to -- a little
short-sighted.

Evolution is a far more complex, chaotic,
and interesting process than that. Plenty

of behaviors could just be accidents of evolution
-- late paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould called

these accidents "spandrels," or traits that
rather than being "adaptive" just stuck around
as byproducts of other processes.

Today we define instincts as complex, unlearned
behaviors that have a fixed pattern throughout

a species. For example, dogs instinctively
shake their fur when wet, salmon return to

the stream in which they hatched, and human
babies know how to suckle just minutes after
being born.

These are true, genetically-predisposed instincts
that do not require learning.

But today we understand that while certain
tendencies may be genetic, individual experience

plays a major role in behavior and motivation,
as well.

So another theory of motivation suggests that
a physiological need, or drive, simply compels

us to reduce that need. This is called the
drive-reduction theory. This can be as simple

as hearing my stomach growl, and looking for
a burrito. My need is food, my drive is hunger,
my drive-reduction behavior is burrito.

Drive reduction is all about maintaining your
body's homeostasis -- the physiological balance
of its systems.

As much as we're pushed to reduce our drives,
we're also pulled along by incentives — the

positive or negative stimuli that either entice
or repel us. The mouth-watering smell of that

burrito pulls me toward it, just as much as
my hunger pushes me there.

However, we're also clearly more complicated
than our homeostatic systems, and drive-reduction

theory may over-simplify a lot of our behavior.
For example, a person may fast for days, ignoring

their body's hunger to honor some spiritual
or political cause; and I know I'm not the

only one who sometimes eats when I'm not actually
hungry.

So a third theory -- the theory of optimal
arousal -- attempts to fill in some of those

gaps. It suggests rather than just reducing
a drive or tension, like hunger, we're motivated

to maintain a balance between stimulation
and relaxation.

Say you're holed up in your house all weekend
studying. You're bored and lonely and gettin'

weird, so you call up some friends to go mountain
biking or to a karaoke bar or whatever you
like to do to for stimulation.

The idea here is that you want to hit the
right level of arousal -- which, take note,

psychologists often use in a non-sexual sense
-- without getting overstimulated and stressed.

So if you nearly break your face on that bike
ride, or if the Journey covers at karaoke

start getting too intense, you may need to
back off and take a nap.

Of course everyone has a different level of
optimal arousal, and I'm guessing Aron Ralston's

was fairly high. Adrenaline junkies may jump
out of planes to hit their ideal level, whereas

others might be satiated by an engaging book,
or new knitting pattern. No matter which,

the optimal arousal theory suggests that we're
motivated to avoid both boredom and stress.

And obviously not all needs are created equally.
If I'm suffocating and can't catch a breath,

I'm not going to be thinking about eating
that burrito. And if I'm about to be ravaged

by lions, I'm not going to worrying about
my paycheck.

American psychologist Abraham Maslow illustrated
this shuffling of priorities in the mid-1900's
with his famous hierarchy of needs.

Down at the bottom of the pyramid you'll find
our most basic physiological needs for food,
water, air, and moderate temperatures.

The next rung up speaks to our need for safety,
then comes love and belonging, followed by

esteem or respect, and finally, once all those
needs have been met, we have the relative

luxury of being motivated by self-actualization
and spiritual growth, and yoga retreats and
stuff.

Of course there are problems with Maslow's
vision. Empirical research hasn't really supported

his hierarchy. We tend to skip around on that
pyramid all the time, and the importance of

those higher-level needs may vary depending
on our culture and finances and personalities.

But still, everyone is restricted by the lowest
levels of the pyramid. So, regardless of the

theories about why we have them, most schools
of psychological thought agree that we are

driven by at least three big motivators: sex,
hunger, and the need to belong.

We'll do a whole lesson later about all sorts
of sex-related stuff, including how it motivates

us. There's a lot there. For now, let's just
say that sexual motivation is how we promote

the survival of our species through recreation
and/or procreation - both of which help human

communities bond and expand. Without it, none
of us would be here today, thinking about
burritos and severed arms and sex and stuff.

Internally, we are biologically driven to
knock boots by our sex hormones. We're also

motivated by psychological and sociocultural
influences - ranging from suggestive external

stimuli plastered all over billboards, magazines,
and TVs in the form of, you know, scantily-clad

bodies sprawled out on beaches to more genteel
desires like love, family, or adherence to
personal, religious, or cultural values.

Sex is a big motivator, but it isn't precisely
a need, no matter what anyone has told you.
People do not die without it.
Hunger, though...

After air and water, food is our body's greatest
need, and thus obtaining food is one of our
greatest motivations.

Hunger may seem pretty simple. Eat food, stay
alive. But physiologically and psychologically,

there is a lot going on. And like so many
things, it starts in the brain.

The sensation of hunger usually begins with
a drop in your blood-sugar level. Glucose

is our body's primary source of energy, and
while you might not initially feel it drop,
your brain will.

Your hypothalamus monitors your blood chemistry,
and responds to both high levels of the "hunger

hormone" ghrelin, and low levels of glucose
by triggering that feeling of hunger reminding

you to eat something. I am in fact experiencing
it right now!

Once you've eaten that burrito, your metabolism
takes over, converting that food into energy.

But while our physiological need for calories
varies depending on our body size and composition,

your gender, and your age, our hunger is also
shaped by our psychology, culture, and mood.

And these factors don't just rule when we're
hungry, they also guide what we're hungry
for.

Biologically speaking, most humans, and many
other animals, have a genetic taste for sweets

and fatty foods, because they're typically
high in energy. But other taste preferences
are conditioned through experience and culture.

I may have an aversion to oysters because
they once made me sick, and love gingerbread

cookies because my grandma used to make them.
Although popular in Cambodia, I'm not too

keen on eating fried tarantulas, just as lots
of folks around the world think that the very
idea of peanut butter is gross.

Still, the feeling of hunger affects us the
same.

During World War Two in the US, some conscientious
objectors volunteered for medical research
as an alternative way to serve their country.

Perhaps the most famous of these studies was
physiologist Ancel Keys' Minnesota Hunger

Experiment, which measured the effects of
semistarvation, by partially starving its
volunteers.

While ethically dubious, the experiment was
geared toward understanding the many small

and large effects of hunger, which was plaguing
Europe at the time.

The study started in 1944, by feeding 36 young,
healthy men a normal diet for three months,

then halving their caloric intake for six
months, then slowly rehabilitating them to
normal weight during the last three months.

They ate mostly wartime-foods like root vegetables,
bread, and pastas, and were required to walk

22 miles, and participate in various work
and educational activities, for 40 hours each

week. The goal was to see a 25 percent drop
in body weight during the starvation period.

As you can imagine, the changes were dramatic.
The men became gaunt and listless, and showed

a decrease in strength, heart rate, and body
temperature.

But the psychological effects were perhaps
even more dramatic. The men became totally

obsessed with food. They dreamed about it,
talked about it all the time, read cookbooks.

They lost interest in sex and jokes and social
activities. They were irritable, anxious,
and depressed.

In the end, they were all rehabilitated, but
the study gave us some understanding of the

devastating psychological effects of starvation.
It also showed us something of the social

effects, as the men withdrew from one another
and isolated themselves. As one fundamental

need was frustrated, these men experienced
the decline of another - the need to belong.

Humans are social animals. Evolutionarily
speaking, it's fair to say that social bonding

has helped us survive. It's a tough world
out there, and we've got a lot better shot

at thriving if we're sharing resources and
responsibilities, protecting and supporting
each other in groups.

That isn't say you need to be joined at the
hip with everyone--our social needs have to

be balanced with our autonomy, or sense of
personal control, so we feel both connected
and independent.

But sometimes we're denied that sense of belonging.
We've all experienced the pain of being ignored

or rejected at some point in our lives. It's
worse than just about anything.

The evidence for this is abundant - one recent
study suggested that teenagers who had a sense

of belonging to their community had better
health and emotional outcomes than those who
didn't feel like they belonged.

Cultures all over the world actually use ostracism,
or social exclusion, as a type of punishment.

Whether it's kids in time-out, adults in exile,
or prisoners in solitary confinement, separation
feels like a punch in the gut.

Never underestimate the power behind what
motivates us. The need to survive, the need

to belong... if you can harness that motivation,
you can do just about anything. Just ask Aron
Ralston.

If you were motivated to learn today, hopefully
you took in four theories of motivation including

the evolutionary perspective, drive-reduction,
optimal arousal, and Maslow's hierarchy of

needs, and how sex, hunger, and the need to
belong motivate us.

Thanks for watching, especially to our Subbable
subscribers who make this whole channel possible.

If you'd like to sponsor an episode of Crash
Course or even be animated into an upcoming
episode, just go to Subbable.com/CrashCourse.

This episode was written by Kathleen Yale,
edited by Blake de Pastino, and our consultant

is Dr. Ranjit Bhagwat. Our director and editor
is Nicholas Jenkins, the script supervisor

is Michael Aranda, who's also our sound designer,
and the graphics team is Thought Café.

title: The Power of Motivation: Crash Course Psychology #17
